description: From Middle English encombraunce, from Old French encombrance, from encombrer.

entries.meaning: Something that encumbers; a burden that must be carried.
examples: Some consideration was necessary to decide whether or not to leave his rifle there. On the return, carrying the girl and a pack, it would be added encumbrance [â€¦]

entries.meaning: (property law) An interest, right, burden, or liability attached to a title of land, such as a lien or mortgage.
(law) One who is dependent on another.
examples: a widow without encumbrances, i.e. without children

verbs.description: encumbrance (third-person singular simple present encumbrances, present participle encumbrancing, simple past and past participle encumbranced)

entries.meaning: (law) To apply an encumbrance to (property, etc.).
